You probably want to convert them to their string representation first using something like this first: https://t.co/yoN4ZJeecZ

RT @the_ethernaut: Solidity trivia #34:

You have a public view function in a contract. Can it know whether it's been called as part of a t‚Ä¶
@therealjfrantz Probably 0 in remix but the real value of the previous block when targeting an actual chain
@staringispolite An example of what I had in mind: https://t.co/kv28osz9Ts
@nnnnicholas ü•∞
@staringispolite Mhhh I see. I can‚Äôt think of a way to do that off the top of my head, that would be extra nasty ü§î

@staringispolite That‚Äôs really the only use case I can see for now. Imagine a shifty contract that looks reasonable to marketplaces but tricks you into acceptable something you didn‚Äôt expect. Prompted by this discussion: https://t.co/vz0rf7tZIU

Now the thing is, the values used in this off-chain check can be spoofed. And maybe in fact they should, with values that look more in line with regular transactions.

Does anyone do this when invoking view functions? https://t.co/uCbPvPtiD1

Based on this table, we can come up with a crude off-chain detector

DM me if you see ways to improve it! https://t.co/adbGE1KHIj

I'm sure there are more sophisticated ways to do it, but things like sender addresses and gas parameters by default give a strong signal that code is evaluated off-chain

https://t.co/7CkWkardLj

Why do we care? Because that makes it possible to have contract code display some data to a frontend (like a rate/price/royalties %) but actually bait-and-switch with different data when the transaction lands on-chain.

Ever wondered what values like msg.sender and tx.gasprice are when you're in a view function? 

TLDR they can be anything when they're evaluated off-chain, and indeed they vary wildly by provider. Which opens up the possibility to fingerprint when we're evaluated off-chain (üßµ) https://t.co/5zHahguzMP
@kieran_eth Maybe call it Ethereum+ and have a couple different profiles for your household members

@isiain @ourZORA In one sense, do you really own an NFT if you get 0% of proceeds from selling it? It's definitely weird, right? 

I can imagine this working if it's clearly advertised (and maybe for a charity), but I could also imagine users feeling scammed / exploited

@isiain @ourZORA But that means it's up to the marketplace to interpret that payout "request" and cap it to something that's at least legal (like 100% in Zora's case), or even lower to something more "usual".

In the Showtime marketplace we ended up capping royalties payouts at 50%
@isiain @ourZORA EIP-2981 is super open-ended, right? It's interesting but also dangerous that the protocol allows literally anything as the royalty payout (not just a fixed % like most ppl assume)

My latest hobby is checking out NFT marketplaces that support on-chain royalties and seeing how they deal with royalties that are larger than the sale amount

@ourZORA v3 supports up to 100% royalties https://t.co/K5RFctoYcQ

The joy of verifying a contract that was deployed by someone else and left unverified for months https://t.co/kE6ZMpG3FA

@zak_krevitt This is a very exciting and powerful technique, but is also sufficiently arcane that most working programmers have never used it directly. @leonardoalt is an absolute mad lad (in a good way) to do something like this *in Solidity* ü§Ø

@zak_krevitt Symbolic execution lets you avoid giving a concrete value to your inputs. So instead of operating on e.g. some number (like 42), you run your program with some symbolic value (like x). So it lets your virtually explore more (all?) of the possible execution paths instead of 1

@zak_krevitt Hey Zak! It's kind of hard to explain in a tweet but I'll give it a try üòÖ

When you run a test, you explore 1 execution path in your code. You  pick some arbitrary input, and check that the output is correct for that input. Nerds call that a "concrete" execution.

@dumbnamenumbers It depends on your speed tolerance, this post really is about erroneously set max priority fee

My queries probably overestimate a bit, I think I get the occasional MEV bot that intentionally sets very high values for maxFeePerGas and maxPriorityFeePerGas, not sure how to exclude these

ü§ì if you're a data/sql whiz, can you sanity check my queries? Thanks!

Some of these results are surprising, e.g. over 1750 ETH overpaid on OpenSea, but when I submit a bid I see a reasonable max priority fee (so the OpenSea frontend seems to do the right thing). Are people using alternative frontends or outdated wallets? https://t.co/1RcsKny2Vm

As a dev, make sure you're not explicitly passing a gasPrice option when you submit a transaction. It is deprecated (use maxFeePerGas if you have to instead)

I suspect this is the main cause of these big max priority fees

(üëã @ricmoo can you confirm?)

Quick reminder: as a user, always double check the suggested gas price before sending a transaction.

See screenshots for bad vs good -- on mainnet 1.5-2.5 gwei is typically good enough. If you see hundreds in there, you are definitely overpaying by a lot https://t.co/ItMm3rK2Mt

Trying to quantify how much has been overpaid by users because max priority fee is set too high:

https://t.co/Qh0y4iIElG https://t.co/izZeuW0hWp https://t.co/wJjCqANmd8

This is like ordering something for $100 and choosing to leave a very generous but completely unnecessary $130 tip.

As a user, you need to double check and edit the suggested gas fee every time, 1.5 gwei priority fee is enough to be included in a block

Solidity people are doing crazy gas optimizations

Meanwhile some frontends still suggest transactions with a max priority fee set to max fee

Example:
- this user could have paid 68.2 base fee + 1.5 priority fee = 69.7 gwei
- instead they paid 162.1 gwei, 2.3x too high https://t.co/7xUcg7z9RM
